It includes the developer console server and the console web frontend through which developers upload and manage their apps published to Accrescent. Parcelo currently features:

- User registration allowlisting
- New app submissions, app updates, and description edits

...and more.

Supporting Accrescent allows us to continue developing Parcelo to enable Accrescent to be the secure and featureful app store we envision.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/accrescent/parcelo", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/accrescent/parcelo/blob/main/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}, {"guid": "accrescent", "name": "Accrescent", "tags": ["android", "security", "privacy", "appstore", "mobile"], "licenses": ["spdx:ISC"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://accrescent.app", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "Accrescent is a novel Android app store focused on security, privacy, and usability. It is built around modern Android features to deliver a pleasant user experience while enforcing modern security and privacy practices and offering robust validity guarantees for installed apps.

This project represents the Accrescent client app which runs on users' Android devices.

Some of Accrescent's features include:

- App signing key pinning: first-time app installs are verified so you don't have to trust our servers
- Signed server metadata: server contents are cryptographically protected against malicious tampering
- Automatic, unattended, unprivileged updates (Android 12+): updates are handles seamlessly in the background without relying on privileged OS integration
- Designed for split APKs: downloaded APKs are optimized for your device to save bandwidth
- No remote APK signing: developers are in full control of their app signing keys
- No account required: users don't need an account to install apps, improving privacy

For more details, see our features page at https://accrescent.app/features.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/accrescent/accrescent", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/accrescent/accrescent/blob/master/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}]}

- musl libc

- tcc (tiny C compiler)

go-orbitdb will provide Go developers with the ability to integrate peer-to-peer, decentralized databases into their applications and synchronize databases deployed other OrbitDB systems.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/orbitdb/go-orbitdb", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/orbitdb/go-orbitdb/raw/refs/heads/main/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}, {"guid": "encryption", "name": "Encryption", "tags": ["programming", "cryptography", "data", "database", "decentralized", "dapp", "privacy"], "licenses": ["spdx:MIT"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbitdb", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbitdb/raw/refs/heads/main/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "OrbitDB is incorporating encryption into its core functionality, allowing developers to encrypt data at both the individual record and entire database level.

Through a modular design, developers will be able to select the best encryption model for them application; some developers may opt for symmetric encryption for simplicity while others may require asymmetric encryption for records not intended for the creator. Some developers may require both, for example, when building a two-way chat system.

Encryption will allow OrbitDB to compete as a viable alternative to traditional, centralized database systems.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbitdb", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbitdb/raw/refs/heads/main/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}, {"guid": "voyager", "name": "Voyager - OrbitDB Pinning", "tags": ["programming", "cryptography", "data", "database", "decentralized", "dapp", "privacy", "p2p"], "licenses": ["spdx:MIT"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbit-db-pinner", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbit-db-pinner/raw/refs/heads/main/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "Voyager is OrbitDB's pinning server.

Because of its peer-to-peer nature, OrbitDB cannot guarantee a user's database will always be available. In the case browser-based applications leveraging OrbitDB, as soon as the machine is offline, the data is no longer available until the machine returns to an online state.

Pinning allows databases to be replicated even if the source machine is offline. It also offers a great way to back up data, ensuring multiple copies but also guaranteeing the user owns and controls the source database.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbit-db-pinner", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/orbitdb/orbit-db-pinner/raw/refs/heads/main/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}]}

{"entity": {"name": "MetaBrainz Foundation Inc", "role": "owner", "type": "organisation", "email": "support@metabrainz.org", "phone": "001-805-459-0815", "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://metabrainz.org/about", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "The MetaBrainz Foundation is a non-profit organization founded in 2004 by Robert Kaye,  creates and maintains open data projects that provide reliable structured metadata for various forms of media.It seeks to build free and accessible knowledge repositories and foster collaboration within an open community. The foundation operates under an open data and open-source ethos, with its data and tools freely available for public use, distribution, and modification. We encourage developers, researchers, and organizations to contribute and create derivative projects, ultimately enriching the ecosystem around open media metadata.
MetaBrainz's flagship project, MusicBrainz, is an extensive, user-driven music database for artist, album, track, and release information. It supports applications like Picard for digital music libraries tagging and serves as a foundational resource with contributions from users and support from companies like Google and the BBC.
ListenBrainz focuses on recording and analyzing music listening habits, inspired by projects like Last.fm. Users can use these insights to explore trends and personalized recommendations.
BookBrainz is an open database for book metadata, similar to MusicBrainz but tailored for literature, cataloging authors, works, editions, and other entities in the literary world. This open data is invaluable for libraries, researchers, and readers seeking a community-driven book database.
The MetaBrainz Foundation‚Äôs commitment to open-source is integral to its mission. All software including the tools, APIs, and data structures, is released under open-source licenses. This transparency ensures the data remains free for everyone, regardless of commercial or non-commercial use, while encouraging contributions from a global user base.
MetaBrainz is funded by partnerships, sponsorships, and community donations, allowing it to remain independent and committed to providing high-quality, free data for users and the digital landscape."}, "funding": {"plans": [{"guid": "one-time-15", "name": "Fifteen dollars one time donation", "amount": 15, "status": "active", "channels": ["paypal", "bank", "credit-card"], "currency": By making this data freely accessible, BookBrainz promotes knowledge sharing and fosters a deeper understanding of the literary world.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/metabrainz/bookbrainz-site", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/metabrainz/bookbrainz-site/blob/master/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}, {"guid": "musicbrainz", "name": "MusicBrainz", "tags": ["music", "community", "metadata", "open-data", "data-service-provider", "non-profit"], "licenses": ["GPL-2.0-or-later", "CC-BY-NC-SA-3.0", "CC0-1.0"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://musicbrainz.org", "wellKnown": "https://musicbrainz.org/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "MusicBrainz is a community-maintained open source encyclopedia of music information. This means that anyone ‚Äî including you ‚Äî can help contribute to the project by adding information about your favorite artists and their works.
 In 2000, Gracenote took over the free CDDB project and commercialized it, essentially charging users for accessing the very data they themselves contributed. In response, Robert Kaye founded MusicBrainz. The project has since grown rapidly from a one-man operation to an international community of enthusiasts that appreciates both music and music metadata. Along the way, the scope of the project has expanded from its origins as a mere CDDB replacement to the true music encyclopedia MusicBrainz is today.
 As an encyclopedia and as a community, MusicBrainz exists only to collect as much information about music as we can. We do not discriminate or prefer one 'type' of music over another, and we try to collect information about as many different types of music as possible. Whether it is published or unpublished, popular or fringe, western or non-western, human or non-human ‚Äî we want it all in MusicBrainz.
 The MusicBrainz Database stores all of the various pieces of information we collect about music, from artists and their releases to works and their composers, and much more. Note: We do not actually store or have access to any of the music recordings!
 Most of the data in the MusicBrainz Database is licensed under CC0, which effectively places the data into the Public Domain. That means that anyone can download the data and use it in any way they want. The remaining data is released under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 license.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/metabrainz/musicbrainz-server", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/metabrainz/musicbrainz-server/blob/master/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}, {"guid": "listenbrainz", "name": "ListenBrainz", "tags": ["music", "community", "recommendations", "fresh-releases", "listening-data", "open-data", "data-service-provider", "non-profit"], "licenses": ["GPL-2.0-or-later", "CC-BY-NC-SA-3.0", "CC0-1.0"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://listenbrainz.org", "wellKnown": "https://listenbrainz.org/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "ListenBrainz is a free and open-source project (similar to Last.fm) that tracks your music listening habits and provides insights into your taste. By submitting your listening data, you contribute to a larger dataset that benefits the music community. ListenBrainz offers visualizations of your listening history, personalized recommendations, and the ability to connect with other music enthusiasts. It's a valuable tool for music lovers who want to understand and share their musical preferences. From the user submitted data ListenBrainz creates several derivative datasets that can be used to build recommendation systems and music discovery tools, free of the bias that is commonly present in closed recommendation systems.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/metabrainz/listenbrainz-server", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/metabrainz/listenbrainz-server/blob/master/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}]}

One of the goals of Flock is to keep girls interested in computing in high school/secondary school. These nodes/parameters can have attributes, which allow to declare many of their properties, such as their values, types, units, ranges, etc. This OSC tree-based architecture  can then be exposed over the network under several protocols, some of which allow this architecture, and the properties and values of its nodes, to be fully explored and queried. {"entity": {"name": "Pratham Books", "role": "owner", "type": "organisation", "email": "purvi.shah@prathambooks.org", "phone": "9341982701", "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://storyweaver.org.in/", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "Research shows learning to read in mother tongue languages reduces dropout rates and makes education engaging and meaningful for children yet UNESCO reports that 40% of the global population lack access to education in a language they know. In the multi-ethnic countries of the Global South, millions of children are unable to read or learn effectively due to critical shortages of quality local language reading resources. 
 StoryWeaver from Pratham Books addresses the book gap by providing an open repository of quality storybooks in multiple languages to promote reading acquisition among children. Simple tools embedded on the platform allow users to further translate and version books for localized requirements and publish these resources on StoryWeaver, creating a multiplier effect and amplifying impact. This has led to a massive increase of local language books on the platform with 65000 books available in over 370 languages, which have been read over 200 million times in 150 countries. Of these, 58% are in minority and indigenous languages, where books are scarce or non-existent and where children have often read a book in their own languages for the first time. This kind of scale has been possible through our communities of practice model. Nurturing these communities lets us distribute our ability to solve for literacy through a societal platform. 
 While the platform is digital, the books are available in multiple formats to overcome the issue of digital access and can be read online, offline or downloaded and printed. StoryWeaver is recognised as a Digital Public Good by the Digital Public Goods Alliance as India's first vetted digital public good for early reading. 
 StoryWeaver is built on Rails, a web application framework with its front-end on ReactJS. The third-party libraries we use are also open source. During 2018, when Room to Read adopted White Labeled code version of StoryWeaver, we open sourced that version of the code base under the MIT license."}, "funding": {"plans": [{"guid": "development-migration-costs", "name": "Total funding plan", "amount": 9800000, "status": "active", "channels": ["prathambooks-bank-channel"], "currency": "INR", "frequency": "other", "description": "One time technical migration and code open sourcing costs for creator and translator tools. This includes product management, design, development, testing, deployment and maintenance efforts. This also includes the underlying infra, storage and compute engine costs"}], "history": [{"year": 2022, "taxes": 0, "income": 187867106, "currency": "INR", "expenses": 157537265, "description": ""}, {"year": 2023, "taxes": 0, "income": 167525159, "currency": "INR", "expenses": 173890094, "description": ""}, {"year": 2024, "taxes": 0, "income": 147425727, "currency": "INR", "expenses": 176296500, "description": ""}], "channels": [{"guid": "prathambooks-bank-channel", "type": "bank", "address": "AccountName:Pratham Books, AccountNumber:231010100122153, AccountType:Savings, Bank:axis, Branch:Kasthuri Nagar, Bangalore, IFSC:UTIB0001446", "description": "We accept mainly direct bank transfers only"}]}, "version": "v1.0.0", "projects": [{"guid": "storyweaver", "name": "multilingual-open-tools-for-creation-and-translation", "tags": ["community-publishing", "multilingual-translations", "language-technology", "open-knowledge", "cultural-preservation", "content-dissemination", "multilingual-platform", "community-development", "technology-migration", "open-source"], "licenses": ["spdx:MIT", "spdx:CC-BY-4.0"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://storyweaver.org.in/en", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "Over the years, StoryWeaver has come to serve millions of users. Yet, the platform struggles with performance at scale as certain technologies in the overall architecture turn outdated. Partnerships with CBSE and Punjab Education Dept.,  saw a huge increase in daily traffic and a 100x spike in concurrent users creating stories. This underlined the need for updating our creation and access microservices to robustly serve users. 
 The World Economic Forum has predicted that 1.1 bn Indians will have access to the Internet by 2030, with 80% primarily using mobile devices and accessing language content. To reach the next generation of internet users, content creation and access must be designed to serve needs of the underserved communities, ensuring that new users are not just connected but empowered. To this effect, we have made structured investments into technical capacities to onboard communities, such as supporting Unicode for the Chakma language, enabling the Chakma community to write their first-ever story on StoryWeaver. Suchana, a community organization, created a unique multi-year program that took Santali children from their home language to the school language to English. StoryWeaver helped support bilingual formats and publishing of stories with 3 different scripts for Santali - Bengali, Olchikki & Devanagiri. 
 This grant will help StoryWeaver complete our technology migration and open-source our inclusively designed stack that allows for creation, translation, publishing and dissemination of content in 300+ languages. While StoryWeaver‚Äôs current pathways enable publishing under creative commons and innovations on access such as offline library via browser cache, the ecosystem can further contribute capabilities such as multi-license publishing and collaborative translations. With StoryWeaver as a continued steward, open-sourcing the stack will enable developers to create multilingual community platforms for use-cases beyond picture book creation.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/PrathamBooks/sw-docker", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/PrathamBooks/sw-docker/blob/master/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}]}

{"entity": {"name": "eGovernments Foundation", "role": "maintainer", "type": "organisation", "email": "gunjan.jain@egovernments.org", "phone": "918041255708", "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://egov.org.in/", "wellKnown": "https://egov.org.in/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "eGov Foundation is a 20-year old non-profit organisation that leverages the power of technology to improve public service delivery. We started with developing software to enable delivery of essential services to citizens effectively and transparently e.g., we developed a complaint resolution system to submit, track, and resolve citizen complaints. 
 
 We realized that the entire ecosystem (private sector, civil society and the government) needs to come together for better public service delivery. With this realization, we built a Free and Open Source Software called DIGIT (Digital Infrastructure for Governance & Inclusive Transformation). It consists of reusable services (e.g., authentication, payment, workflow) that enable a multi-tenanted platform-based architecture. The ecosystem reuses these services to build solutions that digitize public service delivery at speed and scale. 
 
 Since then, the ecosystem has built 50+ solutions on DIGIT, across 10+ sectors (Health, Sanitation, Water, Legal, Climate, etc.), impacting over 2+ billion lives globally, sometimes with eGov's support. eGov maintains DIGIT's open Core, and enables the ecosystem to build and deploy solutions on DIGIT. For example, eGov supported SELCO in building an incident management system for solar grids. This is live and being rolled out across 12 states in India. Many private sector players are building on DIGIT independently. For example, one of the System Integrators has set-up a DIGIT Practice of 150+ people in India and has built 10+ solutions in multiple sectors such as Industrial Estate Mgmt, Inland Water Transport Mgmt. 
 
 DIGIT needs to be governed and managed in keeping with OSS community best practices to ensure that it is closer to the needs of the people (contributors) and sustainable beyond eGov as sole maintainer. We are looking for funding to build a thriving community of contributors to DIGIT Core."}, "funding": {"plans": [{"guid": "community-events", "name": "Community Events", "amount": 400000, "status": contributors for DIGIT (the open source platform on which solutions are built to better deliver public services). The ecosystem (market, civil society and the government) has built 50+ solutions on DIGIT, across 10+ sectors (Health, Sanitation, Water, Legal, Climate, etc.), impacting over 2+ billion lives globally. 
 
 The objective of this project is to ensure long-term sustainability of DIGIT Core supported by a thriving community of contributors. Today, eGovernments Foundation contributes code to DIGIT Core. Our goal is to have 25% of DIGIT Core's new contributions by the community in the next 3 years. The global community would bring their diverse perspectives to solve problems and build together. 
 
 We will use the funds for community-building activities such as 
 1) Establish the role of a DIGIT Community Lead to engage the community by conducting events such as regular webinars, workshops to guide users through DIGIT's functionalities, hackathons and community challenges to inspire creativity and provide a platform for users to showcase innovative solutions. 
 2) Define pathways for involvement, like code contributions, bug reports, and documentation. Create opportunities for non-code contributors (e.g., documentation, marketing, user testing) to build a diverse community. Celebrate and reward contributors by acknowledging their work in newsletters, community calls. 
 3) Create educational content and learning pathways for users at different skill levels such as how-to guides, certifications and recognized courses to motivate community members to deepen their knowledge on DIGIT and contribute more effectively. 
 4) Establish community-led governance for DIGIT Core through code contribution, code reviews, dedicated maintenance, regular feedback sessions, etc.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/egovernments/Digit-Core", "wellKnown": "https://github.com/egovernments/Digit-Core/blob/master/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}]}

{"entity": {"name": "Toucaan‚ÄîIntrinsic Web Design Framework", "role": "owner", "type": "individual", "email": "marvindanig@gmail.com", "phone": "+14159907903", "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://github.com/Toucaan/toucaan", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "I'm a backend developer who is interested in modern frontend technologies. For the past two years, I've been consumed by the world of CSS, its inner workings, its long-held assumptions that no longer hold true, and the limitations of responsive web design itself.

I believe that the design systems today are pinned to an outdated philosophy from the past, and we're at the precipice of a new design ideology that offers better, simpler, and more maintainable options.

The latest standards and accessibility features, plus wider support across vendors, make it imperative to explore our CSS tooling ground-up. I want to be able to devote 100% of my time to Intrinsic Web Design and Toucaan for the next twelve months.

PS: Personally, I like the resilience aspect of FOSS the most, and despite the rise of LLMs & GPTs, I prefer writing code with my bare hands. :-P"}, "funding": {"plans": [{"guid": "hosting-monthly", "name": "Hosting support", "amount": 100, "status": "active", "channels": ["mercury"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "monthly", "description": "This will cover the monthly server hosting costs for the projects."}, {"guid": "developer-time", "name": "Developer compensation", "amount": 14000, "status": "active", "channels": ["mercury"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "monthly", "description": "This will cover the cost of one developer working full-time on the project."}, {"guid": "developer-evangelism", "name": "Evangelism expenses", "amount": 2000, "status": "active", "channels": ["mercury"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "monthly", "description": "This will cover the cost of one evangelist working part-time spreading the word and creating case studies."}], "history": [{"year": 2024, "taxes": 0, "income": 0, "currency": "USD", "expenses": 600, "description": "I don't fully understand the expectation here."}], "channels": [{"guid": "mercury", "type": "bank", "address": "6000 Poplar Ave, Suite 300, Memphis, TN 38119", "description": "Will accept direct bank transfers. Please e-mail me for details."}, {"guid": "bitcoin", "type": "other", "address": "", "description": "1PWHez4zT2xt6PoyuAwKPJsgRznAKwTtF9"}]}, "version": "v1.0.0", "projects": [{"guid": "m2cron", "name": "m2cron", "tags": ["cron", "daemon", "devops"], "licenses": ["spdx:GPL-3.0"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://rdmp.org/dmbcs/mcron", "wellKnown": "https://rdmp.org/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "A modern replacement for GNU Mcron and older cron daemons.

A cron daemon has been in all the various UNIX implementations since the beginning, and was FOSS ºd by Paul Vixie who thereby provided the de-facto standard.  These programs run other programs at regular intervals, without operator intervention.

GNU Mcron first appeared around 2003, and served the dual aims of providing a full Vixie cron replacement, and giving users new freedoms in determining when jobs run.  The GUIX project used GNU Mcron heavily since its inception, and the GNU Mcron project was donated to the GUIX project in 2017, who now look after it.

M2cron throws off the Vixie compatibility, increases the potential to control when jobs run, and provides for better real-time interaction with the daemon, which can run as a root process so that regular users can leave jobs to run once their sessions have ended.", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://rdmp.org/dmbcs/mcron.git", "wellKnown": "https://rdmp.org/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}}]}

{"entity": {"name": "Kandra Labs, Inc.", "role": "steward", "type": "organisation", "email": "support@zulip.com", "phone": "", "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://zulip.com/values", "wellKnown": "https://zulip.com/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "Guiding the Zulip community in developing a world-class organized team chat product with apps for every major desktop and mobile platform requires leadership from a talented, dedicated team. We believe that the only sustainable model is for our core team to be compensated fairly for their time. We have thus founded a company (Kandra Labs) to steward and financially support Zulip‚Äôs development. We are growing our business sustainably, without venture capital funding. VCs are incentivized to push companies to gamble for explosive growth. Often, the result is that a company with a useful product burns rapidly through its resources and goes out of business. We have built Zulip as a sustainable business (also supported by SBIR grants from the US National Science Foundation), and are being thoughtful about our pace of spending. Funding our company without venture capital also allows us to live by our values, without investor pressure to compromise them when doing so might be ‚Äúgood business‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat everyone does‚Äù."}, "funding": {"plans": [{"guid": "github-sponsors", "name": "Support Zulip", "amount": 0, "status": "active", "channels": ["github-sponsors"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "monthly", "description": "Contribute to Zulip's development and free hosting for open source projects and other worthy organizations!"}, {"guid": "patreon", "name": "Support Zulip", "amount": 0, "status": "active", "channels": ["patreon"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "monthly", "description": "Contribute to Zulip's development and free hosting for open source projects and other worthy organizations!"}, {"guid": "open-collective", "name": "Support Zulip", "amount": 0, "status": "active", "channels": ["open-collective"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "monthly", "description": "Contribute to Zulip's development and free hosting for open source projects and other worthy organizations!"}], "history": null, "channels": [{"guid": "github-sponsors", "type": "payment-provider", "address": "https://github.com/sponsors/zulip", "description": "Preferred channel for sponsoring Zulip, since GitHub Sponsors does not charge any fees to sponsored projects."}, {"guid": "patreon", "type": "payment-provider", "address": "https://patreon.com/zulip", "description": ""}, {"guid": "open-collective", "type": "payment-provider", "address": "https://opencollective.com/zulip", "description": ""}]}, "version": "v1.0.0", "projects": [{"guid": "zulip", "name": "Zulip", "tags": ["communication", "team-chat", "collaboration"], "licenses": ["spdx:Apache-2.0"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://zulip.com/", "wellKnown": "https://zulip.com/.well-known/funding-manifest-urls"}, "description": "Zulip is an open-source team chat application designed for seamless remote and hybrid work. With conversations organized by topic, Zulip is ideal for both live and asynchronous communication. Zulip‚Äôs 100% open-source software is available as a cloud service or a self-hosted solution, and is used by thousands of organizations around the world. An important part of Zulip‚Äôs mission is ensuring that worthy organizations, from programming-language developers to research communities, are able to use Zulip whether or not they have funding. Alaveteli is the world‚Äôs leading free open source software powering Access to Information platforms - helping people use their right to request information from public authorities, and opening up the information released in a searchable public archive. {"entity": {"name": "Damian Ravi", "role": "owner", "type": "individual", "email": "damian.ravi.work@gmail.com", "phone": "", "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://pyrebrowser.com", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "I studied Economics to develop a new system of resource distribution that would aleviate all of the planets problems. Finally in 2023, with my experience I began working on a revolutionary browser that could save the planet by excising all predatory aspects of our current global economy."}, "funding": {"plans": [{"guid": "pyre-floss-grant", "name": "FLOSS GRANT REQUEST", "amount": 100000, "status": "active", "channels": ["pyre-browser-bank", "pyre-browser-eth"], "currency": "USD", "frequency": "one-time", "description": "Request for funding grant from FLOSS."}], "history": [], "channels": [{"guid": "pyre-browser-bank", "type": "bank", "address": "ACCOUNT NUMBER: 43478165 :: SORT CODE: 20-92-60 :: SWIFTBIC: BUKBGB22 :: IBAN: GB45 BUKB 2092 6043 4781 65", "description": ""}, {"guid": "pyre-browser-eth", "type": "other", "address": "ETH/BSC/GLMR ADDRESS: 0x72733E5e53C5f78dd5a98A531f3C77038F90dead", "description": ""}]}, "version": "v1.0.0", "projects": [{"guid": "pyre-browser-project", "name": "Pyre Browser", "tags": ["browser", "p2p"], "licenses": ["spdx:GPL-3.0"], "webpageUrl": {"url": "https://pyrebrowser.com", "wellKnown": null}, "description": "Pyre Browser is a Decentralized P2P browser that liberates the world from predatory markets. We created the project with a deep concern for the direction of the planet and environment.

It is a normal HTTPS browser (thats 44% faster than Firefox) but also has a secondary P2P internet. If I type in aol.com it will go to the main website. If I type in aol it will take you to a 404 page where you can purchase the domain. After the site is purchased you can upload a folder and save the checksum to the blockchain. Every time a user searches for your domain their client will look for a 7z folder with the same checksum as noted on the blockchain and download it from peers. If you want to change the website you just upload the new folder and save again (It costs 0.1 cent in Glimmer to do this). Each user is then prompted to download the new version from peers.

The project includes PyrETH - a web3 alternative that is 16x smaller in size than the original and embedded in the browser. It also includes Polkadot extrinsics for cross chain compatability natively. We created this to make injected web3 code much more intuitive and faster for web developers. The DNS server is hosted on Moonbeam and allows for instant purchase and reselling of web domains. Uploading updated websites costs a fraction of a cent for web owners and is done with a simple upload dropbox in the DNS panel.


A strange fact...

There are 200 million active websites and the average size of them is around 2mb. In total this is around 400 terabytes only.
200,000,000 x 2MB = 400TB
It costs around $3000 to buy a 500 terabyte harddrive - The entire hosted internet (excluding image/video data) could fit on $3000 worth of storage!

Using 7zip compression we can lower the total figure to 240 terabytes. This is nothing! ...and yet the hosting industry totals to around $600bn. Google, Microsoft and Amazon use around 60tWh of energy each year. This is more than the bottom 170 countries in the world", "repositoryUrl": {"url": "https://pyrebrowser.com/repo", "wellKnown": null}}]}
